questions.definition: Blood vessels that carry oxygen-rich blood away from the heart to the rest of the body. Example: These vessels are often felt as a pulse in your wrist.
Blood vessels that carry blood back to the heart. Example: These vessels are often visible under the skin.
The smallest blood vessels where oxygen and nutrients are exchanged with cells. Example: These connect arteries to veins.
Tiny air sacs in the lungs where oxygen is transferred to the blood. Example: These structures look like little clusters of grapes.
Cells in the blood that transport oxygen to the body's tissues. Example: These cells contain a protein called hemoglobin.
The liquid part of blood that carries nutrients, hormones, and waste products. Example: It makes up more than half of the bloodâ€™s volume.
The muscular tube that moves food from the mouth to the stomach. Example: This tube contracts in a wave-like motion called peristalsis.
A long, coiled tube where most digestion and nutrient absorption occurs. Example: This organ is about 6 meters long in adults.
The organ where water is absorbed and solid waste is formed. Example: It surrounds the small intestine like a frame.
A large organ that produces bile to help digest fats and detoxifies the blood. Example: This organ is located on the right side of the abdomen.
An organ that produces enzymes for digestion and hormones like insulin. Example: This organ is located behind the stomach.
A hollow organ that stores urine before it is excreted. Example: This organ expands like a balloon as it fills.
A dome-shaped muscle that helps with breathing by expanding the chest cavity. Example: You can feel this muscle working when you take a deep breath.
The two large tubes that branch off the trachea and lead to the lungs. Example: These tubes are part of the pathway for air entering the lungs.
The part of the throat that connects the mouth and nasal passages to the esophagus and larynx. Example: This is where food and air paths cross.
The part of the throat that contains the vocal cords and produces sound. Example: This is often called the 'voice box.'
A bundle of nerves running through the backbone that transmits signals between the brain and body. Example: Damage to this structure can cause paralysis.
A flexible connective tissue found in joints and other areas like the nose and ears. Example: This tissue prevents bones from rubbing directly against each other.
Tissue that connects bones to other bones at joints. Example: A sprain occurs when this tissue is stretched or torn.
Tissue that connects muscles to bones. Example: The Achilles tendon connects the calf muscle to the heel.
The soft tissue inside bones that produces blood cells. Example: Found in the hollow center of larger bones like the femur.
The body's largest organ, which protects against infection and helps regulate temperature. Example: It has layers like the epidermis and dermis.
An automatic response to a stimulus, controlled by the nervous system. Example: Pulling your hand away from a hot stove.
Structures in the skin that produce sweat to help cool the body. Example: These glands are most active when you're exercising or in hot weather.
The body's reaction to harmful invaders like bacteria or viruses. Example: This can include producing antibodies.
